questions.text: Identify the following dermatologic condition associated with McCune-Albright syndromes
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cafe`-au-lait spots Image shows Café-au-lait spots. Note the two topographical variants: in (a) the spot has a smooth ‘coast of California’ border, whereas the upper spot in (b) has an irregular ‘coast of Maine’ border. Café-au-lait spots: These are coffee-coloured macules of variable size (from a few mm to 10 cm). Multiple lesions are associated with NF 1 and McCune–Albright syndromes. They are more common in dark-skinned races .

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Mongolian Spot : A Mongolian spot is a congenital blue-grey macule found on the sacral skin. Option: C. Spitz Naevus : These are reddish brown (occasionally deeply pigmented) nodules, previously termed ‘juvenile melanoma’. They most commonly occur on the face and legs, growing rapidly initially then remaining static or regressing Option: D. Naevus Spilus(Speckled lentiginous nevus) : These are similar in appearance to café-au-lait spots but with hyperpigmented speckles throughout.

questions.text: Identify the condition appear at birth shown in the picture
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Port-wine stain The above given image shows Port wine stains which are intensely purple stained ,flat and on the neck.

Highyeild:

Capillary vascular malformations (‘port-wine stains’ (PWS) are 20 times less common than capillary hemangioma and result from defective maturation of cutaneous sympathetic innervation during embryogenesis, leading to localized intradermal capillary vasodilatation. They appear at birth as flat, smooth, intensely purple-stained areas , most frequently on the head and neck, often within the maxillary and mandibular dermatomes of the trigeminal nerve. Treatment with intense pulsed light and pulse dye laser are successful. PWS may be associated with various syndromes.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Salmon Patch: A salmon patch is a vascular malformation that presents as a pinkish macule, usually at the nape of the neck. It is caused by an area of persistent fetal dermal circulation that usually disappears at 1 year. Option: B. Strawberry Haemangioma: This is the commonest ‘birthmark’, occurring most frequently on the head and neck Ninety per cent are present at birth; as a consequence of intravascular thrombosis, fibrosis and mast cell infiltration, 10% resolve each subsequent year, with 70% resolved by 7 years old. White skin is affected most commonly and girls are affected three times more than boys. Option: D. Campbell de Morgan Spot: These are arteriovenous fistula at the dermal capillary level in sun-exposed skin of older patients.

questions.text: Most common malignancy in a transplant recipient is
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Squamous cell carcinoma After transplantation, there is an increased risk of developing most types of malignant disease but the risk is particularly high for those types of tumors in which viral infection plays an aetiological role. The increased risk of malignancy is particularly high for skin cancer and PTLD (Post-transplant lymphoproliferative disorder). Most of the skin cancers seen are squamous cell carcinomas, but basal cell carcinoma and malignant melanoma are also more common than in the general population. The risk of skin cancer after transplantation rises with age and exposure to sunlight, and it has been predicted that 50% of transplant recipients will develop a skin malignancy within 20 years of transplantation.

Highyeild:

questions.text: Most common type of Malignant Melanoma is
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Superficial spreading melanoma Superficial spreading melanoma (SSM) : This is the most common presentation (70%), usually arising in a pre-existing nevus after several years of slow change, followed by rapid growth in the preceding months before presentation.

Highyeild:

Malignant Melanoma : Melanoma is a cancer of melanocytes and can, therefore, arise in skin, mucosa, retina and the leptomeninges. Epidemiology : Exposure to UVR Common among young adults Rising Incidence Macroscopic Features : Change in size Shape Colour Thickness (elevation/nodularity or ulceration) Satellite lesions (pigment spreading into surrounding area) Tingling/itching/serosanguineous discharge (usually late signs) Four variants : Superficial Spreading Melanoma Nodular Melanoma Lentigo Melanoma Acral Lentiginous Melanoma Miscellaneous : Amelanotic Melanoma Desmoplastic Melanoma Staging : Summary of the American Joint Committee on Cancer melanoma staging, 8th edition. Primary tumour Regional nodes Distant metastases NO No node involvement T1 <1.0 mm a: <0.8 mm, no ulceration b: 0.8-1.0 mm, no ulceration; or <1.0 mm with ulceration N1 1 node a: Micrometastasis (no MSI) b: Macrometastasis (no MSI) c: MSI present M1a Skin, subcutaneous or distant lymph node metastases (normal serum LDH levels) Mm T2 1.01-2.0 a: No ulceration b: With ulceration N2 2 or 3 nodes a: Micrometastasis (no MSI) b: Macrometastasis (no MSI) c: MSI present M1b Lung metastases (normal serum LDH levels) Mm T3 2.01-4.0 T4 >4 mm a: No ulceration b: With ulceration a: No ulceration b: With ulceration N3 a: Micrometastasis, >3 nodes (no MSI) b: Micrometastasis, >3 nodes or matted or 1 clinical node (no MSI) c: >1 clinical or occult node with MSI present M1c All other visceral metastases or any distant metastases with elevated serum LDH levels M1d Brain metastases Clinical staging of melanoma Stage 0: Tis, NO, MO Stage la: T1a, NO, MO Stage Ib: T1b or T2a, NO, MO Stage Ila: T2b or T3a, NO, MO Stage Ilb: T3b or T4a, NO, MO Stage Ilc: T4b, NO, MO Stage III: any T, >N1, MO Stage IV: any T, any N1, M1 Treatment : Complete Excision For melanoma in situ a wide excision of 5 mm is sufficient; for melanoma <1 mm deep, a 1-cm margin is sufficient; and for deeper lesions, a 2-cm only margin is recommended Prognosis : Breslow thickness is the most important prognostic indicator

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Nodular melanoma (NM) tends to be more aggressive than SSM, with a shorter clinical onset. They typically appear as blue/black papules,1–2 cm in diameter, and because they lack the horizontal growth phase, they tend to be sharply demarcated. Option: C . Lentigo maligna melanoma (LMM) was previously also known as Hutchinson’s melanotic freckle. It presents as a slow-growing, variegated brown macule on the face, neck or hands of the elderly. Option: D . Acral lentiginous melanoma (ALM) ALM affects the soles of feet and palms of hands. It usually presents as a flat, irregular macule in later life. 25% are amelanotic and may mimic a fungal infection or pyogenic granuloma.

Extraedge:

Malignant melanoma is the most common primary malignant tumour of the eye and originates in the pigmented cells of the choroid ,ciliary body or iris. Malignant melanoma of the anus is very rare and usually presents as a bluish-black soft mass that may mimic a thrombosed external pile, although it may be amelanotic Malignant Melanoma Penis is an uncommon tumour with the principles of management being the same as for squamous cell carcinoma. Bloodborne metastatic disease is, however, more common.

options.text: Follicular occlusion followed by folliculitis & secondary infection with skin flora

questions.correct_answer: A. Follicular occlusion followed by folliculitis & secondary infection with skin flora
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Follicular occlusion followed by folliculitis & secondary infection with skin flora Follicular occlusion followed by folliculitis and secondary infection with skin flora (usually Staphylococcus aureus and Propionibacterium acnes) culminates in chronic suppurative, painful, skin abscesses, sinus tracts and scarring. HIDRADENITIS SUPPURATIVA (HS): Follicular occlusion followed by folliculitis and secondary infection with skin flora (usually Staphylococcus aureus and Propionibacterium acnes) culminates in chronic suppurative, painful, skin abscesses, sinus tracts and scarring. HS occurs in skin containing apocrine glands, commonly in the axillae and groins; but also the scalp, breast, chest and perineum. It appears to have a genetic predisposition with variable penetrance, and is strongly associated with obesity and smoking. It affects four women for every man. Patients should stop smoking and lose excess weight. Symptoms can be reduced by the use of antiseptic soaps, tea tree oil and wearing non-compressive and aerated underwear. Medical treatments include topical and oral antibiotics and antiandrogen drugs. In selected cases, patients require radical excision of the affected skin and subcutaneous tissue. Reconstruction after excision avoids contracture and functional impairment.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. HS affects four women for every man Option: C. Reconstruction after excision avoids contracture and functional impairment.

questions.correct_answer: C. Fournier's gangrene is not as same as necrotising fasciitis
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Fournier's gangrene is not as same as necrotising fasciitis Meleney’s synergistic gangrene and Fournier’s gangrene are variants of a similar disease process. Necrotising fasciitis Meleney’s synergistic gangrene and Fournier’s gangrene are variants of a similar disease process It results from synergistic, polymicrobial infection ; most commonly a streptococcal species (Group A β-haemolytic) in combination with Staphylococcus, Escherichia coli, Pseudomonas, Proteus, Bacteroides or Clostridia. Predisposing conditions include: diabetes mellitus; smoking; penetrating trauma; pressure sores; immunosuppression; intravenous drug abuse; perineal infection (perianal abscess, Bartholin’s cysts); and skin damage/infection (abrasions, bites, boils). Classical clinical signs include: oedema stretching beyond visible skin erythema; a woody-hard texture to the subcutaneous tissues; an inability to distinguish fascial planes and muscle groups on palpation; disproportionate pain in relation to the affected area, with associated skin vesicles and soft tissue crepitus. Management should commence with urgent fluid resuscitation, monitoring of hemodynamic status and administration of high-dose, intravenous broad spectrum, antibiotics. This is a surgical emergency and the diseased area should be debrided as soon as possible until viable, healthy, bleeding tissue is reached. Early surgical review and further debridement is advisable, together with the use of vacuum-assisted dressings. Early skin grafting in selected cases may minimize protein and fluid loss.

Solution:

Dermoid cyst Dermoid cysts account for about half of childhood orbital neoplasms and consist of keratinized epithelium and adnexal structures such as sweat glands and hair follicles.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option A : Meibomian Cyst (Most common lid swelling) A meibomian cyst is a chronic granulomatous inflammation of a meibomian gland It may occur on either upper or lower lids and presents as a smooth, painless swelling Option B : Trichilemmal Cyst Trichilemmal (pilar/pilosebaceous) cysts are derived from the epidermis of the external root sheath of the hair follicle; 90% are found in the scalp and 70% are multiple. They are usually distinguished from epidermal cysts by pathologists, rather than clinically Option C : Sebaceous Cyst These cysts are lined with true stratified squamous epithelium, derived from hair follicle infundibulum or traumatic inclusion. Commonly known as sebaceous cysts, they can occur anywhere. They are fixed to the skin and usually have a central punctum

questions.text: Juvenile melanoma is otherwise known as
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Spitz naevus Spitz naevus : These are reddish brown (occasionally deeply pigmented) nodules, previously termed ‘juvenile melanoma’. They most commonly occur on the face and legs, growing rapidly initially then remaining static or regressing. The differential diagnosis is melanoma and excision biopsy are warranted if there is doubt as to the diagnosis.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Junctional nevus: A junctional nevus is a dermo-epidermal proliferation of naevus cells, visible as deeply pigmented macules or papules that occur commonly in childhood or adolescence, usually progressing to form compound or intradermal naevi with advancing age. Benign mucosal lesions tend to be junctional naevi. Option: C. Intradermal naevus : Intradermal naevi are faintly pigmented papules in adults showing no junctional proliferation, but a cluster of dermal melanocytes Option: D.Compound naevus: This is a maculopapular, pigmented lesion that becomes most prominent during adolescence. It represents a junctional proliferation of naevus cells, with nests and columns in the dermis.

questions.text: Treatments option for Basal cell carcinoma are all except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

None of the above Tumor and surrounding surgical margins should always be assessed and marked under loupe magnification; the latter varying between 2 and15 mm, depending on the macroscopic variant. Where margins are ill-defined, or tissue at a premium (nose, eyes) then either a two-stage surgical approach with subsequent reconstruction after confirmation of clear margins, or Mohs’ micrographic surgery is advisable.

Highyeild:

Basal Cell Carcinoma : Slow growing Risk factor – UVR 90% nodular/nodular cystic High- and low-risk BCC Macroscopic Features : Localized - nodular, nodulocystic, cystic, pigmented and naevoid Generalized - superficial: multifocal and superficial spreading; or infiltrative: morphoeic, ice pick and cicatrising Microscopic Features : Characteristic finding is of ovoid cells in nests with a single ‘palisading’ layer Prognosis : High Risk Large (>2 cm); Located at sites where direct invasion gives access to the cranium (near the eye, nose and ear) Recurrent tumors Tumors forming in the presence of immunosuppression Micronodular or infiltrating histological subtypes Management : Surgical : Tumor and surrounding surgical margins should always be assessed and marked under loupe magnification, the latter varying between 2 and 15 mm depending on the macroscopic variant Non -Surgical : Radiotherapy, Topical Treatment (5-Fluorouracil,imiquimod)

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B .Mohs’ micrographic surgery is a method used by dermatological surgeons (dermatologists who have undergone extra training in techniques of cutaneous surgery and histopathology) to excise skin cancer under microscopic control. Option: C .In the elderly or infirm patients, radiotherapy produces similar recurrence rates to surgery; but with the risk of generating further malignancy after 1–2 decades. Biopsy-proven, superficial tumors can be treated with topical treatments (5-fluorouracil, imiquimod).

Extraedge:

Naevoid basal cell carcinoma (Gorlin’s) syndrome This is an autosomal dominant inherited condition caused by an abnormal tumour suppressor gene on chromosome 9q 22–31 coding the ‘patched’ protein; 90% of patients develop multiple basal cell carcinomas (BCCs) Trichoepithelioma These are small skin-coloured nodules found most often in the nasolabial folds. Trichoepithelioma is clinically and histologically similar to a BCC Trichilemmoma is a congenital hamartoma with the appearance of a linear verrucous naevus; 10% lifetime risk of forming a BCC

questions.text: Gorlin syndrome associated with which type of skin malignancy
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Basal cell carcinoma Naevoid basal cell carcinoma (Gorlin’s) syndrome : This is an autosomal dominant inherited condition caused by an abnormal tumor suppressor gene on Ch. 9q 22-31 coding the ‘patched’ protein. 90% of patients develop multiple basal cell carcinomas (BCCs). Patients may exhibit specific phenotypic characteristics including: over developed supraorbital ridges; broad nasal roots; hypertelorism; bifid ribs; scoliosis; brachy-metacarpals; palmar pits and molar odontogenic cysts.

questions.text: Ovoid cells in nests with a single 'palisading' layer is typically seen in
questions.explanation:
Solution:

BCC Localized (nodular; nodulocystic; cystic; pigmented and naevoid) Generalised (superficial: multifocal and superficial spreading; or infiltrative: Morphoeic, ice pick and cicatrizing). Nodular and nodulocystic variants account for 90% of BCC. Basal cell carcinoma- Microscopic features: Twenty-six histological subtypes have been described. The characteristic finding is of ovoid cells in nests with a single ‘palisading’ layer. It is only the outer layer of cells that actively divide, explaining why tumor growth rates are slower than their cell cycle speed would suggest, and why incompletely excised lesions are more aggressive. Morphoeic BCCs synthesize type 4 collagenase and so spread rapidly.

questions.text: Breslow thickness is the most important prognostic indicator for?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Malignant melanoma The Breslow thickness of a melanoma (measured to nearest 0.1 mm from granular layer to base of tumor) is the most important prognostic indicator in the absence of lymph node metastases. The likelihood of metastatic spread to regional lymph nodes is proportional to the Breslow thickness of the melanoma. SNB (Sentinel Node Biopsy) in melanoma is currently a staging investigation for patients with tumors of Breslow thickness >1 mm.

questions.text: Hutchinson's sign is related with which carcinoma
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Melanoma MM under the finger nail are usually SSM rather than ALM. For finger or toe nail lesions it is vital to biopsy the nail matrix, rather than just the pigment on the nail plate. A classical feature of a subungual melanoma is Hutchinson’s sign : nail fold pigmentation that widens progressively to produce a triangular pigmented macule with associated nail dystrophy. The differential diagnosis is ‘benign racial melanonychia’, which produces a linear dark streak under a nail in a dark skinned individual. Malignancy is unlikely if the nail fold is uninvolved.
